Class ImageProcessing

java.lang.Object
ImageProcessing
public class ImageProcessing extends Object
This ImageProcessing class has some methods I wrote that are useful to image processing

  • Method Summary

    Modifier and Type
    Method
    Description
    static int[][]
    BilinearInterpolate(int[][] img, int inWidth, int tgWidth)
    An inplementation of bi-linear interpolation, this method overload is for down-sampling the brushes, equivalent to BilinearInterpolate(img, inWidth, inWidth, tgWidth, tgWidth, false)
    static int[][]
    BilinearInterpolate(int[][] img, int inWidth, int inHeight, int tgWidth, int tgHeight, boolean inZeroPad)
    An inplementation of bi-linear interpolation, if the input image is zero-padded, this method would automatically aligns it to be a perfect up-scale, otherwise this is a semi-naive implementation that has the same pixel shifting problems, an improved version with a half pixel offset won't benefit the painting anyway:
    static int[][]
    BoxFilter(int[][] img, int width, int height, int filterSize)
    Apply a odd-number-sized box filter to a grayscale image
    static double[][]
    Conv1DTwoPass(int[][] img, double[] kernel, int width, int height, int kernelSize)
    Apply a two-pass 1D convolution to a grayscale image, can be used for separable kernels like gaussian kernel, box filter kernel or sobel kernel, this implementation only supports kernels of odd-numbered size for simplicity
    static double[][]
    Conv2D(int[][] img, double[][] kernel, int width, int height, int kernelSize)
    Apply a 2D convolution to a grayscale image, this implementation only supports square 2D kernels of odd-numbered size for simplicity, written for debug purpose only
    static double[][]
    GaussianBlur(int[][] img, int sigma, int width, int height)
    An implementation of gaussian blur that uses a 1D gaussian filter, the filter size equals to (6*sigma)+1, this filter size captures almost the whole bell shape and provides a great balance between efficiency and accuracy, a two-pass 1D convolution is utilized to gaussian blur the image at a reasonable speed
    static double[][]
    GaussianBlur2D(int[][] img, int sigma, int width, int height)
    FOR DEBUG USE ONLY, can be used to verify the result of the GaussianBlur method which uses two-pass 1D convolution with a 1D gaussian kernel instead of the very inefficient 2D gaussian kernel used here
    static int[][]
    GrayScaleImage(ImagePPM img)
    Creates the grayscale version of an image (equal RGB weighting)
    static int[][]
    MDoG(int[][] img, int width, int height, int[] sigmas)
    Calculates the Multi-scale Difference of Gaussians of a grayscale image, for every sigma (standard deviation) passed in, an unsigned DoG is calculated by subtracting GaussianBlur(img, sigma) from GaussianBlur(img, 2 * sigma)
    static int[][]
    PadBorder(int[][] img, int pad, char method, int width, int height)
    Pad a grayscale image at its borders, the padding method defaults to zero padding but reflection padding provides the best effect for edge detection purpose
    static int[][]
    SobelMagnitude(int[][][] img, int width, int height)
    Create a sobel magnitude map of a colour image, the magnitudes across all three colour channels are combined via a maximum operation, does not use a two-pass 1D convolution because the input image can be rather high and the performance gained is insignificant
    static void
    Threshold(int[][] img, int threshold, int width, int height)
    Threshold a grayscale image at a set threshold value

    • Threshold

      public static void Threshold(int[][] img, int threshold, int width, int height)
      Threshold a grayscale image at a set threshold value
      Parameters:
      img - input image (grayscale or one colour channel)
      threshold - the threshold value
      width - img's row number
      height - img's column number

      public static int[][] GrayScaleImage(ImagePPM img)
      Creates the grayscale version of an image (equal RGB weighting)
      Parameters:
      img - input image
      Returns:
      int[][] grayscale image

    • BoxFilter

      public static int[][] BoxFilter(int[][] img, int width, int height, int filterSize)
      Apply a odd-number-sized box filter to a grayscale image
      Parameters:
      img - input image (grayscale or one colour channel)
      width - img's row number
      height - img's column number
      filterSize - size of the box filter (must be a positive odd integer)
      Returns:
      int[][] filtered image

    • MDoG

      public static int[][] MDoG(int[][] img, int width, int height, int[] sigmas)
      Calculates the Multi-scale Difference of Gaussians of a grayscale image, for every sigma (standard deviation) passed in, an unsigned DoG is calculated by subtracting GaussianBlur(img, sigma) from GaussianBlur(img, 2 * sigma)
      Parameters:
      img - input image (grayscale or one colour channel)
      width - img's row number
      height - img's column number
      sigmas - the standard deviation
      Returns:
      int[][] Multi-scale Difference of Gaussians

    • GaussianBlur2D

      public static double[][] GaussianBlur2D(int[][] img, int sigma, int width, int height)
      FOR DEBUG USE ONLY, can be used to verify the result of the GaussianBlur method which uses two-pass 1D convolution with a 1D gaussian kernel instead of the very inefficient 2D gaussian kernel used here
      Parameters:
      img - input image (grayscale or one colour channel)
      sigma - standard deviation of the gaussian function
      width - img's row number
      height - img's column number
      Returns:
      double[][] filtered image, double is used instead of int for accuracy

    • GaussianBlur

      public static double[][] GaussianBlur(int[][] img, int sigma, int width, int height)
      An implementation of gaussian blur that uses a 1D gaussian filter, the filter size equals to (6*sigma)+1, this filter size captures almost the whole bell shape and provides a great balance between efficiency and accuracy, a two-pass 1D convolution is utilized to gaussian blur the image at a reasonable speed
      Parameters:
      img - input image (grayscale or one colour channel)
      sigma - standard deviation of the gaussian function
      width - img's row number
      height - img's column number
      Returns:
      double[][] filtered image, double is used instead of int for accuracy

    • Conv1DTwoPass

      public static double[][] Conv1DTwoPass(int[][] img, double[] kernel, int width, int height, int kernelSize)
      Apply a two-pass 1D convolution to a grayscale image, can be used for separable kernels like gaussian kernel, box filter kernel or sobel kernel, this implementation only supports kernels of odd-numbered size for simplicity
      Parameters:
      img - input image (grayscale or one colour channel)
      kernel - 1D kernel
      width - img's row number
      height - img's column number
      kernelSize - size of the 1D kernel
      Returns:
      double[][] filtered image

    • Conv2D

      public static double[][] Conv2D(int[][] img, double[][] kernel, int width, int height, int kernelSize)
      Apply a 2D convolution to a grayscale image, this implementation only supports square 2D kernels of odd-numbered size for simplicity, written for debug purpose only
      Parameters:
      img - input image (grayscale or one colour channel)
      kernel - 2D kernel
      width - img's row number
      height - img's column number
      kernelSize - size of the 2D kernel
      Returns:
      double[][] filtered image

    • SobelMagnitude

      public static int[][] SobelMagnitude(int[][][] img, int width, int height)
      Create a sobel magnitude map of a colour image, the magnitudes across all three colour channels are combined via a maximum operation, does not use a two-pass 1D convolution because the input image can be rather high and the performance gained is insignificant
      Parameters:
      img - input image (grayscale or one colour channel)
      width - img's row number
      height - img's column number
      Returns:
      int[][] unsigned sobel magnitude map

    • PadBorder

      public static int[][] PadBorder(int[][] img, int pad, char method, int width, int height)
      Pad a grayscale image at its borders, the padding method defaults to zero padding but reflection padding provides the best effect for edge detection purpose

      method 'R': reflection padding

      method 'r': reflection padding (only reflect row, zero pad columns)

      method 'c': reflection padding (only reflect column, zero pad rows)

      Parameters:
      img - input image (grayscale or one colour channel)
      pad - number of pixels that needs to be padded at each border
      method - default: zero padding
      width - img's row number
      height - img's column number
      Returns:
      int[][] padded image

    • BilinearInterpolate

      public static int[][] BilinearInterpolate(int[][] img, int inWidth, int inHeight, int tgWidth, int tgHeight, boolean inZeroPad)
      An inplementation of bi-linear interpolation, if the input image is zero-padded, this method would automatically aligns it to be a perfect up-scale, otherwise this is a semi-naive implementation that has the same pixel shifting problems, an improved version with a half pixel offset won't benefit the painting anyway:

      - Only sobel magnitude maps (which are zero-padded) are upsampled

      - Only the brushes are downsampled (they also need to go through a rotation, which would flatten the marginal gain in accuracy completely)

      Parameters:
      img - input image
      inWidth - input image's width (row number)
      inHeight - input image's height (column number)
      tgWidth - target image's width (row number)
      tgHeight - target image's height (column number)
      inZeroPad - whether the input has been zero-padded
      Returns:
      int[][]

    • BilinearInterpolate

      public static int[][] BilinearInterpolate(int[][] img, int inWidth, int tgWidth)
      An inplementation of bi-linear interpolation, this method overload is for down-sampling the brushes, equivalent to BilinearInterpolate(img, inWidth, inWidth, tgWidth, tgWidth, false)
      Parameters:
      img - input image
      inWidth - input image's width (row number)
      tgWidth - target image's width (row number)
      Returns:
      int[][]
